column1:
Report on the Website about bse:

The topic of the report is the BSE (Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy) crisis that occurred in the UK in the 1990s. The disease, also known as mad cow disease, was caused by a prion (a type of infectious protein) that was transmitted to humans through the consumption of contaminated beef products.

The report provides an overview of the crisis, including its causes, symptoms, and impact on the food industry and human health. It also discusses the measures taken by the UK government and the European Union to contain the outbreak and prevent future occurrences.

The main points of the report are as follows:

* BSE was first identified in 1986 in a cow in England
* The disease was caused by a prion that was transmitted through contaminated animal feed, which was made from rendered cattle carcasses
* Symptoms of BSE included changes in behavior and coordination, followed by progressive brain damage and death
* The disease affected over 180,000 cows and led to the destruction of millions of tons of beef products
* Human consumption of contaminated beef products led to the transmission of BSE to humans, resulting in a condition called variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (vCJD)
* The UK government and the European Union implemented measures to contain the outbreak, including the slaughter of infected animals, the disposal of contaminated animal feed, and the regulation of the cattle industry
* These measures helped to prevent further occurrences of BSE and vCJD, but they also had significant economic and social impacts on the affected communities.

Overall, the report provides a comprehensive overview of the BSE crisis and its impact on human health and the food industry.	Доклад на сайте о б с е.	Доклад на сайте ОБСЕ.	258141	LETTERS
